Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A bar mitzvah ceremony that has been planned for months is scheduled to happen.
Story: I walk through the door, the familiar scent of home wrapping around me, and see my husband slouched on the couch, his tie loosened, eyes tired. “Rough day?” I ask, and he shrugs, trying to play it off, but I know him well enough to see the tension in his jaw. I want to sit beside him, listen, offer comfort, maybe make his favorite tea. But my phone buzzes—a reminder about the bar mitzvah I’m officiating tonight. Months of preparation, a family counting on me, a young boy waiting for this moment. I glance at the clock. I have just enough time to change and leave. My husband looks at me, hopeful, needing a few minutes of my attention. The congregation expects me to be present, composed, a guide for their celebration. My husband expects me to be his partner, his support. I stand in the hallway, coat in hand, heart pulled in two directions, feeling the weight of both promises pressing down on me.
